bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê pêyak nâpâw wiya piko êh-pêyakokamikisit pisisik mâna . Once upon a time a certain man always dwelt off along with his family.

kîtahtawê namoya wîhkâc apiyiwa owîkimâkana , tahto-kîsikâw êh-sipwêhtêyit , kâh-wâwêsihoyicih , ayôwinisa êh-miywâsiniyikih tahto-kîsikâw êh-posiskahk awa iskwêw . After a while his wife never stayed at home, but went off every day, after putting on her fine clothes; every day that woman put on her good clothes.
kîspin piyê-kîwêcih , mistahi mâna mâyâtaniyiwa , konta mâna misiwê ê-asiskîwiyikih . When she came back home, they were always in a bad state, muddied all over.

tânêhki êtokê
itêyihtam awa nâpêw : “I wonder what this means?” thought the man;
mahtih nika-kakwê-wâpamâw , itêyihtam . “Suppose I watch her,” he thought.
tâpwê mâcîhkâsôw . So he pretended to go hunting.

êkwah kîmôc pêh-wâh-wîskawahtâw wîkiwâw , mahtih ê-wîh-kiskinawâpamât owîkimâkanah , tântêh isi kitah-sipwêhtêyit . Then he gradually stole up to the lodge, to watch his wife and learn which way she would go.
kâ-wâpamât aspin otah sakâhk êy-isi-sipwêhtêyit , kiskêyimêw itêh êh-itohtêyit . When he had seen her go off into the woods, he knew where she was going [no translation]

kâ-wâpamât êkotê sakâhk wâkayôsah ê-wâh-owîcimosiyit , mistahi kisiwâsiw , êh-ohtêyimât ôhi wâkayôsah . [no translation: He saw her there in the bush, she had a bear for a lover, he was very angry and jealous of the bear.]
wâpahkih nika-nipahâw ! itêyihtam . “Tomorrow I shall kill him!” he thought.

tâpwê êh-otâkosiniyik , ômisi itwêw awa :
anohc wâkayôs nimiskawâw itah êh-ôwâtit , itwêw awa nâpêw , êh-kîwêt . So then in the evening he said, “Today I found a bear's den,” said the man, when he came home.
êkwah ômisih itwêw anah iskwêw ; ômisih êsah kîh-itik ôhih wîcimosah wâkayôsah : Then the woman spoke thus; for thus she had been told by her lover, the bear:
kîspin nipahikawiyâni , otinâhkan nipahkêkin , kîh-itik êsa ; “If I am slain, do you then take my hide,” he must have told her;

êkosi itâp ntawêyihtamani pikw îspihk ayîsiyiniwak mihcêt kika-nipahâwak , kîh-itik êsa awa iskwêw ; “In this way, later, should you so desire, you may at any time kill many people,” he must have told that woman;

êkosi ômisih itêw onâpêma :
êkâya misiwê pîkoswâhkan . so now she said to her husband, “Do not cut him up.
tâpiskôc atâwâkan kây-isi-pahkoniht , êkosih isîhâhkan , kîh-itêw êsa onâpêma . Just as one skins a fur-bearing animal for sale, do you so prepare him,” she told her husband.
êhag , itwêw awa nâpêw , ê-sîhkimikot wîwa . “Very well,” said the man, in answer to his wife's request.
tâpwê wîhpi-pahkonêw ôhi , ispîhk êh-ntawi-nipahât ôhi wâkayôsa . So he cut the creature out of its hide, when he went to kill that bear.

ômisi itwêw an îskwêw :
namoya kacâc ta-môwâyahk ! The woman said, “We do not have to eat him, do we?”
îkamâ mâka awiyak kêh-kîh-mowât êh-owîcimosiyit ! itêw owîkimâkanah . “[no translation]” replied the husband.
êkosi tâpwê kîsihêw ôhi wâkayôsiwayânah . Then accordingly she prepared that bearskin.
êkwah ocawâsimisiw awa iskwêw . Then that woman gave birth.
nîso nâpêsisak ayâwêw sêmâk , nîsôtêwa . Even then and no later, she had two boys, twins.
êyakoni wâkayôsah êsah owîtôsêmâ . [no translation]
tâpwê âpihtaw wiyawâhk misiwê ôpîwâwak êsa ôki nâpêsisak . And those boys were covered with fur all over half of their bodies.
êkosi êyiwêhk kitimâkêyimêw awa nâpêw ; Then that man to some extent took pity on them;
êyiwêhk wî-kakwêh-ohpikihêw , âta namoya wiya otawâsimisah . he decided to bring them up as best he could, even though they were not his.
tâpwê ohpikiwak ôki awâsisak . And so those children grew up.

êkwah êh-ati-misikiticik , kîtahtawê ômisih itêw :
êkâya wîhkâc tâpwêhtamok , nitawâsimisitik , âhki kiyawâw
wâkayôsak
itikawiyêko . Then, as they were growing up, at one time he told them, “Never give credence to it my children, if ever you are called ‘bears.’

seg.gloss: If that is said to you, you will change your bodily form.”

p.seg: êkosi tâpwê nama wîhkâc êsa tâpwêhtamwak ôki awâsisak , êkosi êtihtwâwi . Accordingly, those boys never gave heed when they were called that way.

kîtahtawê awa osîmimâs ,
kiyâm wâkayôsiwitân mahtih ! itêw ôhi ostêsah . Then at one time, “Let us turn into bears!” the younger one said to the elder.
tâpwê wâkayôsiwiwak . So they turned into bears.
pê-nôcihêwak awâsisah , êh-pê-pâ-paskatayêpitâcik . They came pursuing the children, and when they reached them, tore them open at the belly.

êkwah kisiwâk wîkiwâhk kâ-pih-nipahihtwâwi ôki maskosisak , sêmâk awa iskwêw kisiwâsiw êsah . Then when, close to the lodge those bear-cubs were killed, at once that woman grew angry. LB on {kâ-pih-nipahihtwâwi}: Why iterative?
nitaw-ôtinêw ôhi kâ-kiy-ôsihât oskotâkayah , ôhi maskwayâna . she went and took that mystic dress she had made, that bear-skin robe.
êkos îsi at-îsi-kwêskîmôw . At once she thus changed her bodily form.
onâpêma ati-nipahêw . she killed her husband.
êkotah ohci mitoni kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwah mêscihêw . Then she killed off all the people.
mitoni êsa êh-mîhcêtihk , êwakoni kahkiyaw mitoni nipahêw . Although there were many of then, she killed them all.
ôkâwiya piko iskohêw . Only her mother she spared.
âtah êh-pâ-pâskisoht , namoya êsa kîh-sâkôcihâw ; Although she was shot at again and again, she could not be overcome;
namoya kîh-nipahâw , piyisk êkos îsi kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwah kâ-kisi-mêscihât . it was impossible to kill her, so that at last she thus had exterminated those people.
êkwah awa oskinîkiw kîwotêw , êwako awa omisa kâ-wâkayôsiwiyit . Then that young man went visiting, whose elder sister was the woman who had turned into a bear.
êkwah awa iskwêw ôhtâwiya iskohêw . ôhcitaw ê-wîh-kakwâtakihât . And that woman had spared her father, only so as to torture him.
tâpwê pêyak mistahi kwâtakiyêw okâwiya , mîna osîmisa pêyak , êwakoni piko êh-iskohât . Truly, she tormented her mother and her little sister, having spared only them.

êkwah mâna pikw îtê ê-papâmâcihot , piyê-takohtêci piko nayêstaw êh-kîhkâmât , nanâtohk êy-isi-kwâtakihât , kiyêkaw ê-saskahwât , misiwê êsa omikiwak ôki kêht-âyak mina aw îskwêsis . When she had been going about here and there, when she came back, she would do nothing but scold them, and torment them in various ways, burning them pell-mell, so that those old people and that little girl were all covered with scars.
mistahi êsah kitimahêw . She kept them in a grievous state.

kîtahtawê awa oskinîkiw kâ-takohtêt ,
tanêhki oma ? itêyihtam , itah ôma kâ-kîh-mihcêtiyit ayîsiyiniwa kahkiyaw êh-mêscihimiht . Presently, when that young man arrived, “What can be the matter?” he thought, since all the many people there had been killed.
pêyak piko mîkiwâhp wâpahtam , ohpimê êh-cimatêyik . He saw only one tipi, standing off to one side.
êkwah kîtahtawê osîmisah kâ-wâpamât , êh-ntawi-tâpakwêyit , wâposwah ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahâyit . Then presently he saw his little sister going out to snare rabbits.
tânêhk ôma k-ôh-ispayik , nisîmis ? itêw . “How has this happened, little sister?” he asked her.

ômis îtêw awa iskwêsis :
ê-kih-mêscihtât kimisinaw . Said the girl, “Because our sister has killed all in the place.
nayêstaw pikoh kôhtâwiyinaw pimâtisiw , itwêw aw iskwêsis . “Only our father is alive,” said the girl.
mistahi pakwâtam awa nâpêw . The man was deeply shocked.
êkwah mistahi namoya ê-sâkôcihiht , âtah êh-pâskisoht , itwêw awa iskwêsis . “And she has not been overcome, even by shooting,” said the girl.

êkosi êkwa ,
tânisi kê-kîh-tôtamân ? itêyihtam awa nâpêw . Then, “What shall I be able to do?” thought the man.

seg.q: pikw êcik âna kita-kakwêcimâyêk tantôwihk onipiwin êh-astêyik .
seg.gloss: “It seems that the only way is for you to ask her where is her mortal spot.

seg.q:
mahtih ,
kêhcinâh awiyak ê-sîhkimikoyêk ! âta wiya kik-êtikowâw .
seg.gloss: ‘Surely someone has put you up to this!’ she will say to you.

seg.q: namoya ! osâm mistahi êh-manitôwiyin , êkâ êh-kîh-nipahikawiyin , kik-êtâwâw .
seg.gloss: ‘No! It is only that you are so greatly endowed with supernatural power, that you cannot be killed,’ you will say to her.”

p.seg: tâpwê kîwêw awa iskwêsis . Accordingly the girl went home.
nîso wâposwa nipahtamâk ôhi ostêsah . Her brother killed two rabbits for her.

ômis îtwêw :
nôhtâh , itêw ,
nistês niwâpamâw , itêw ôhtâwiya ,
êwakoni ôhi ê-nipahtamawit . She spoke thus: “Father,” she said to her father, “I have seen my brother; he it was killed these for me.

seg.gloss: ‘Ask her in what spot a wound would cause her death,’ he says.”

p.seg: âh , tâpwê awa mayaw ôhi êh-takohtêyit , mitoni misiwê êsah êh-miswâkaniwit awa iskwêw . Then truly, as soon as that other had arrived, that woman was wounded all over her body.
êkwah tâpwê kakwêcimêwak . Then accordingly, they asked her.
nama cî ahpôh kikosisiwâw kâ-kêh-kîwotêt niwîh-kakwê-nipahik ? itwêw êsa awa iskwêw . Is it not perhaps that your son who visited here wants to kill me?” said the woman.

seg.q: mâskôc mistahi manitôwiw , êh-itêyimitân , k-ô-nôhtê-kiskêyihtamân tânimatôwihk t-ônipôwiniyan .
seg.gloss: Because I thought of you, ‘Doubtless she is greatly endowed with spirit power,’ is why I wish to know in what part you have your vital spot.”
seg.note: LB on {t-ônipôwiniyan}: The regular formation from {nipiw}: “he dies” would be {nipiwin}: “death” (cf. {onipiwin}: “his death” earlier in this text) and {onipiwiniw}: “he has his death.” But the form here in the text is probably recorded right: {nipôwin}: “death” and {onipôwiniw}: “he has his death” are probably relics of the time when “to die” was an irregular verb, cf. Fox {nepwa}, Menomini {nepoah}: “he dies,” Fox {nepôweni}: “death”.

p.seg: hâ , nôhtâh , âta nikiskêyihtên êh-wîh-kakwê-nipahikawiyân , k-ôh-kakwêcimiyan ! itwêw awa iskwêw ; “Ho, father, I do know that you are asking me because an attempt is to be made against my life!” said the woman;

seg.gloss: “It is in the middle of my foot.”

p.seg: êkwah tâpwê mayaw ê-sipwêhtêyit awa , sêmâk itohtêw awa oskinîkiw , ôhtâwiyah êh-ntawâpamât mîna okâwiya . Then, as soon as she had departed, the young man came to see his father and mother.

seg.q:
hwâ ,
nitâwisitânihk nônipôwinin ; êwak ohci êk âwiyak k-ô-kîh-nipahit , itwêw êsa .
seg.gloss: “Ha, ‘At the sole of my foot is my vital spot; that is why no one can kill me,’ she says.”

p.seg:
êkwah ômis îtwâw awa oskinîkiw :
mistikwa ka-kînîkihkwatamok . Then the young man said, “Point the ends of some sticks. LB on {ka-kînîkihkwatamok}: Normal form probably, {kâ-kînikihkotamok}.

seg.gloss: Then you will stick them upright in the ground everywhere.
Then she will prick herself on them.

p.seg: êkosi êkotah kê-nipahâyahk , itwêw êsah awa oskinîkiw . That is the way we shall kill her,” said the young man.
mayaw ê-sipwêhtêyit , misiwê cimatâwak miscikosah . As soon as she had gone away, they stuck the little slivers everywhere into the ground.

tâpwê ê-takohtêyit ,
mahtih asamik ! êh-itikocik , sêmâk mâcih-kîhkâmêwak . And so, when she came and told them, “Give me to eat!” at once they began to revile her.
kêhcinâh awiyak êkosi ê-kîh-itikoyêk , k-ôh-kâh-kîhkâmiyêk ! itwêw awa iskwêw . “Surely someone has told you to do this, that you all insult me!” said the woman.
êhag ; ôtah kîh-takohtêw nistês , itwêw awa iskwêsis . “Yes; my brother has been here,” said the little girl.
iskotêw êsah ohci pakamahwêw ôhi omisah . And then with a burning brand she struck the woman, her sister.
tâpwê pikoh êkos îsi wayawîyâmôwak . Then at once, they fled out of the lodge.

êkosi êkwah aw îskwêw otihtinêw ôhi oskotâkayah , ôhi mâna k-ôtinât wâh-nipahtâkêcih maskwayânah . Then the woman seized her mystic dress, the bearskin robe which she always took when she was about to kill.

mayaw êh-atih-pimipayit awa iskwêw , mâka mîna êh-kwêskimot , sêmâk otâwisitânihk kisisin . As soon as the woman dashed along, changing, as always, her bodily form, at once she ran a sliver into her sole.
pahkisin êkotah . She fell to the ground.
êkotah êsah kîh-nipahâw êwakoh iskwêw , mihcêt ayîsiyiniwah ê-kîh-nipahât . And so there that woman was slain who had killed so many people.
